snippet: A 48-hour ultimatum to President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt left him with few choices to resolve growing unrest and plunged the military back into the center of politics, less than a year after Mr. Morsi and his Muslim Brotherhood took power.
abstract: Egypt's generals deliver ultimatum to Egyptian Pres Mohamed Morsi, giving him 48 hours to satisfy public's demands, or else military will step in; hundreds of thousands of protesters renew calls for Morsi's ouster, while his Islamists allies vow to take to the streets to stop what they call a military coup.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
byline.contributor: Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting from Cairo, and Michael D. Shear from Tanzania.

lead_paragraph: A 48-hour ultimatum to President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt left him with few choices to resolve growing unrest and plunged the military back into the center of politics, less than a year after Mr. Morsi and his Muslim Brotherhood took power.

headline.sub:
Leader Given 2 Days
to Satisfy Protesters
or Face Takeover
headline.main:
Morsi Faces
Ultimatum as
Allies Speak of
Military ‘Coup’
headline.print_headline: Egyptian Military Gives Ultimatum to Morsi, Whose Allies See ‘Coup’

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
